El militant que fa de conductor accidental del "bus" de campanya de la CUP
La delicada situació econòmica obliga la formació anticapitalista a buscar solucions imaginatives

07 Nov 2019, 16:06

La delicada situació econòmica de la CUP per la pèrdua de diputats al Parlament i de regidors als ajuntaments, que donen part del sou al partit, ha comportat que la formació anticapitalista s’hagi hagut d’estrènyer el cinturó en aquesta campanya electoral. La CUP, que no demana mai crèdits a bancs, ha recorregut a donatius per finançar una campanya que té un cost de poc més de 92.000 euros. Una de les primeres conseqüències ha sigut que no s’ha enviat propaganda electoral als domicilis perquè el cost (246.000 euros) triplicaria la despesa dels cupaires en la cita electoral.
Un altre efecte de la contenció econòmica, menys visible això sí, és que la CUP no ha pogut posar cap autobús per als periodistes que segueixen la campanya. Arran de la demanda d'alguns mitjans que els facilitessin el transport, la formació anticapitalista ha tirat de militància. I aquí entra en escena en Jordi, un militant del partit que ha ofert la seva furgoneta per portar els periodistes als mítings. "Just abans de la campanya van preguntar als militants amb una circular en què podíem ajudar i jo els vaig respondre que disposava d'una furgoneta i que tenia disponibilitat a les tardes", assenyala en Jordi, que viu a Sant Esteve Sesrovires i és director d'un centre de menors. 
No amaga que no s'imaginava que acabaria portant candidats i periodistes a la seva furgoneta. "No havia fet mai de conductor i no m'ho esperava", admet. Després d'aquesta experiència, que l'ha portat a fer únicament els trajectes més llargs, com a Lleida, Reus, Vic i Manresa, deixa clar que li agrada conduir però que no s'hi dedicaria: "És una feina més relaxada, però no és tan divertida com la meva". L'únic ensurt el va tenir anant a Vic, quan es van trobar un control policial a l'autopista. "Vam dubtar si dir que érem de la CUP, perquè només hi havia periodistes i per no tenir problemes, però al final no ens van aturar", explica rient.
text:
The militant who acts as an accidental driver of the "bus" campaign of the CUP
The delicate economic situation forces anti-capitalist formation to seek imaginative solutions

07 Nov 2019, 16:06

The delicate economic situation of the CUP for the loss of Members of the Parliament and councilors in the city councils, which give part of the salary to the party, has meant that the anti-capitalist formation had to tighten the belt in this election campaign. The CUP, which never claims bank loans, has resorted to donations to finance a campaign that has a cost of just over 92,000 euros. One of the first consequences has been that electoral propaganda has not been sent to households because the cost (246,000 euros) would triple the expenses of the criminals in the electoral appointment.
Another effect of economic containment, less visible, is that the CUP has not been able to place any bus for the journalists that follow the campaign. Following the demand of some means to facilitate transportation, anti-capitalist formation has become militant. And here comes the scene in Jordi, a party militant who offered his van to bring the journalists to the meetings. "Just before the campaign they asked the militants with a circular in which we could help and I replied that he had a van and had availability in the afternoon," he says in Jordi, who lives in Sant Esteve Sesrovires and is a director from a children's center.
He does not hide that he did not imagine that he would end up bringing candidates and journalists to his van. "I had never done a driver and I did not expect it," he admits. After this experience, which has led him to do only the longest journeys, such as Lleida, Reus, Vic and Manresa, he makes it clear that he likes to drive but that he would not dedicate himself to it: "It is a more relaxed job, but it's not as fun as mine. " The only scare he had was going to Vic, when they found a police check on the freeway. "We doubted whether to say that we were from the CUP, because there were only journalists and not having problems, but in the end they did not stop us," he says laughing.
